the RMP Prevention Program 3 Elements, additional elements for refineries are included in CalARP Prevention Program 4. These are:
	Safeguard Protection Analysis
	Hierarch of Hazard Controls Analysis
	Human Factors Program
	Process Safety Culture Assessment
	Management of Organizational Change
	Damage Mechanism Review


5.0. Five-Year Accident History
Kern Energy has no history of accidental releases from covered processes that resulted in deaths, injuries, or significant property damage on-site, or known offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage within the last five years.


6.0. Emergency Response Program 
Kern Energy has a comprehensive emergency response program in place to provide prompt but safe response to halt and/or mitigate a release. Kern Energy has worked closely with the Kern County Fire Department (KCFD) in developing its response plan.


7.0 Planned Changes to Improve Safety
Kern Energy has been performing and revalidating Process Hazard Analyses (PHAs) for all its process units on a systematic basis since 1993. The planned changes to improve safety at the facility resolve the recommendations derived from the Process Hazard Analysis, as well as incorporate recommendations from compliance audits and incident investigations as they become available.  The facility has a tracking system for implementing these recommendations and ensuring closure. As required by the regulations, recommendations will be addressed and closed in a timely manner.

Alternative Release Scenario Results Summary for Flammables
Process 1 ARS Description: The alternative release scenario selected was the failure of a transfer pump or the breakaway of a transfer hose during butane unloading, releasing 58,440 lbs of butane, causing a vapor cloud fire (flash fire). No mitigation measure was considered.   Using the parameters mandated by regulations through the RMP*Comp program, this alternative release has the potential to traverse less than a 0.1-mile radius from the point of release and the potential to affect a population of 0 people.


4.0. Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps
Kern Energy has a comprehensive release prevention program in place. Physical safeguards to prevent the release of a regulated substance, including design and construction, to strict national standards; monitoring, alarm, and shutdown systems; extensive operating procedures and training; and rigorous inspection and maintenance routines.

Kern Energy implemented key prevention program elements as part of this Risk Management Program to manage process safety issues associated with the covered processes. In addition, common industry standards, policies, and procedures are currently utilized to ensure safe practices.

Kern Energy facility's RMP Prevention Program 3 and CalARP Prevention Program 4 elements are as follows: 

Common Elements of RMP Prevention Program 3
	Process Safety Information
	Process Hazard Analysis
	Operating Procedures
	Training
	Mechanical Integrity
	Management of Change
	Pre-Startup Safety Review	
	Compliance Audits
	Incident Investigation
	Employee Participation
	Hot Work Permits
	Contractors
	Emergency Planning & Response

Aside from

Executive Summary
This Risk Management Plan Executive Summary was developed pursuant to Section 2745.3 of the California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program codified by Title 19, California Code of Regulations (CCR), Division 2, and Chapter 4.5 and Section 68.155 of EPA Risk Management Plan (Title 40 CFR Part 68). The purpose of this Executive Summary is to provide a brief description of certain elements of the Risk Management Plan that have been implemented at the Kern Energy facility, located in Bakersfield, California. The objectives of the California Accidental Release Prevention Program are to prevent the accidental release of certain regulated substances, minimize the risk to the community, and promote communication between the facility and emergency response personnel. 


1.0. Accidental Release Prevention
Kern Energy is committed to the safety and well-being of its employees, contractors, and the public. Kern Energy's policy is to implement reasonable measures to prevent a release of hazardous material, to provide early detection of a release in the unlikely event that one would occur, and to have in place a contingency plan to respond promptly yet safely to such a release.


2.0. Stationary Source and Regulated Substances
This Risk Management Plan (RMP) has been prepared to address the handling of flammable
regulated substances at the Kern Energy refinery located at 7724 E. Panama Lane, Bakersfield, CA 93307. The refinery handles crude oils and petroleum products containing one or more of the
following flammable regulated substances:

  - Methane
  - Ethane
  - Propane
  - Butane
  - Pentane
  - Hydrogen


3.0 Hazard Assessment Summary
Worst-Case Release Scenario (WCRS) Results Summary for Flammables
